passages.text: The supreme art of war is to subdue the enemy without fighting.
If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.
passages.context: Dual knowledge as foundation of confidence

passages.text: Appear weak when you are strong, and strong when you are weak.
In the midst of chaos, there is also opportunity.
Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt.
passages.context: Contrast between stillness and explosive action

passages.text: Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows. The soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing.
The greatest victory is that which requires no battle.
passages.context: Economy of force as highest art

passages.text: Be extremely subtle, even to the point of formlessness. Be extremely mysterious, even to the point of soundlessness.
Victorious warriors win first and then go to war, while defeated warriors go to war first and then seek to win.
Move swift as the wind and closely-formed as the wood. Attack like the fire and be still as the mountain.
All warfare is based on deception.
He who knows when he can fight and when he cannot will be victorious.
Opportunities multiply as they are seized.
The wise warrior avoids the battle.
passages.context: Wisdom is knowing what not to do

passages.text: Attack him where he is unprepared, appear where you are not expected.
There is no instance of a nation benefiting from prolonged warfare.
Build your opponent a golden bridge to retreat across.
When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard.
Strategy without tactics is the slowest route to victory. Tactics without strategy is the noise before defeat.
passages.context: Balance of long and short term

passages.text: Treat your men as you would your own beloved sons. And they will follow you into the deepest valley.
